content:
Yes, you can do that by using the `groupby()` function and the `size()` function of the dataframe. Here's an example:
```
import pandas as pd

#Read in the csv file
df = pd.read_csv('your_file.csv')

#Create a new dataframe containing each unique combination of the "CPT" column and the "BlueHost" column
df_grouped = df.groupby(['CPT','BlueHost']).size().reset_index(name='counts')

#This new dataframe will have three columns, "CPT","BlueHost" and "counts"
```
You will have to replace 'your\_file.csv' with the name of your csv file. This new dataframe will have three columns, "CPT","BlueHost" and "counts" where "counts" column tells you the number of rows for each unique combination of the "CPT" and "BlueHost" columns.
